item.title: EINSCAN PRO HD
item.dc:creator: cocopuncakes
item.description: Learn more about EINSCAN PRO HD and create your first 3d model from object.
item.content:encoded:
EINSCAN PRO HD

This brief tutorial is designed to help you kickstart your printing journey with the EinScan Pro HD. Follow these simple steps to set up your scanner and start creating high-quality 3D models. Let’s get started!

Start tutorial

Warning Before Scanning Object:

OBJECT TYPE

To scan objects without problems, it is recommended to scan objects that have sufficient geometric features. Objects with few geometric features, such as flat surfaces, are difficult for feature alignment. In such cases, sticking markers on these areas is suggested to ensure accurate scanning and alignment.

NOT RECOMMENDED

  • Living organisms
  • Transparent objects
  • Sensitive electronic devices
  • Fragile or valuable items
  • Highly reflective and shiny surfaces
  • Explosive or flammable materials
  • Biological or chemical hazards

Requirements:

Minimum Configuration:

  • Processor: Intel® Xeon E3-1230, Intel® i5-3470, Intel® i7-3770
  • Display Card: Nvidia Quadro P1000 or higher; Nvidia GTX660 or higher
  • Memory: 8GB RAM
  • Storage: At least 8GB
  • USB: Minimum one USB 3.0 port
  • Screen Display: 1920×1080 resolution

Recommended Configuration:

  • Processor: i7-8700
  • Display Card: NVIDIA GTX1060 or higher
  • Memory: 32GB or more
  • Storage: 32GB or more
  • USB: At least one USB 3.0 port
  • Screen Display: 1920×1080 resolution

If the computer has multiple graphic card, access to the NVIDIA Control Panel (right click on the desktop). In Manage 3D Settings > Program Settings, Add EXScan software. Then change the preferred graphic processor for this program. Select NVIDIA processor. Click Apply to save the settings.

STEP 1

Connect Power and USB

  1. Connect the scanner power line and adapter. Attach the evasion pod to the scanner.
  2. Connect the adapter and evasion line. Plug the USB end of the aviation line into the computer for the industry path.

Check picture

STEP 2

Scanner Calibration

  1. Ensure the software is installed on your system. If not go to installation. Check how to install software here page 14.
  2. Open the installed software. ->
    • Click on the “Calibrate” option following the on-screen instructions.
  3. Positioning the Scanner:
    • Hold the scanner in your hand with the color camera side facing you.
    • Place the calibration board according to the software guidance.
    • Press the button on the scanner to activate capturing.
  4. Capture Process:
    • Follow the on-screen instructions to move the scanner across the calibration board.
    • Capture all positions indicated by the software, ensuring the symbol turns green.
    • The software will automatically guide you to the next position.

It is necessary to calibrate when:

  1. Device Change
  2. Bumpy Transportation
  3. Decreased Accuracy
  4. Bumpy Transportation
  5. No Calibration for 15 Days or More
  6. Plugged in with Color Camera

The acceptable accuracy after calibration in handheld mode is when the result is less than or equal to 0.05mm. If the deviation is more than 0.05mm, recalibration is recommended.

STEP 3

Scan Mode Selection

Use Fixed Scan without Turntable when:

  • High accuracy and high resolution are required;
  • Suitable for objects that are hard to move or too big for turntable scanning.

Use Handheld Rapid Scan mode when:

  • High accuracy and high-resolution handheld scanning are required;
  • Suitable for objects that are hard to move or too big for turntable scanning.

Use Handheld Rapid Scan mode when:

  • A fast scanning experience is needed;
  • Objects with good geometry for feature alignment;
  • Objects are hard to move or too big to stay on turntable for scanning.

Note: If you have imported a global marker file, new markers cannot be added during the scan.

STEP 4

Handheld Scan

  1. Open the scanning software and create a new project or load an existing one.
  2. Choose the desired scanning accuracy level (medium or low) based on your project requirements.
  3. Markers Placement (Optional):
    • Before scanning, place markers (mock points) regularly on the surface of the object using markers or reference points.
    • Ensure even distribution of mock points to enhance tracking during the scanning process.

STEP 5

Brightness Adjustment

  1. Use the software interface to adjust the brightness. Locate the relevant button and make necessary adjustments.
  2. Double-click the Play button to enter/exit the exposure adjustment menu. Adjust brightness by pressing “+”/”-” buttons on the scanner or dragging the cursor left (-) or right (+).

Proper Brightness Setting:

  • Red indicates overexposed, black is underexposed, and white/light grey is optimal.
  • Ensure the brightness is at a level where lines and markers are clearly visible without being overexposed.

TIPS BEFORE SCAN:

  • Choose a suitable background to minimize noise during scanning.
  • Pay attention to the prompt lights on the scanner to ensure optimal distance.
  • Review the software prompts for guidance on distance and lighting conditions.
  • Practice scanning at a constant speed for better results.

Tracking Loss:

  • In case of tracking loss, return to the previous position where scanning was successful and restart the tracking process.
  • Use the distance prompts on both the scanner and software to ensure the proper scanning distance.

STEP 6

Scanning Process

  1. Double-click the start button on the scanner to begin the scanning process.
  2. Observe the adjustment results in real-time. Clear visibility of matte points and projection lines indicates optimal settings.
  3. Maintain a consistent scanning speed for best results.


Not Recommended During the Scan:

  • Moving the Object: It is not recommended to move the object during the scan to maintain the position relationship between the object and markers.
  • Scanning Objects with Simple Features: Objects with simple features like plain, symmetric surfaces such as spheres or cylinders are not recommended for feature alignment

STEP 7

Post-Processing

  1. Once scanning is complete, click the complete button on the software interface.
  2. Use the software tools for simple edits. Select areas with the left mouse button and perform actions like deletion or addition.

3. Manual Alignment:

  • You can scan several times making different projects one folder.
  • Then you can align models placing markers manually. To combine the data, a minimum of 3 markers are required.

Edit menu

  • SHIFT + Left mouse：Select redundant area, the selected section will be displayed in red.
  • Ctrl + Left mouse: Deselect selected data.
  • Click this button or “DELETE” in the keyboard to delete selected data.

STEP 7

Type of mesh Selection

Watertight Model:

  • Characteristics: Every hole in the model is automatically filled, ensuring a seamless and solid structure.
  • Usage: Suitable for direct 3D printing as the model is complete and closed.
  • Processing Time: Generally quicker than creating an Unwatertight model.

Unwatertight Model:

  • Characteristics: The model remains as scanned, with any unclosed parts preserved in the final model.
  • Usage: Helpful when maintaining the original scanned details without any modifications.
  • Mesh Resolution: Does not require selecting a mesh resolution for a watertight finish.

STEP 8

EXPORT

  1. After software meshed your model, click Save to export the data.
  2. By default saving format is .stl.
  3. Go to the next post to learn more how to print your scanned model.
Tutorial

Your First Print

Learn more about Prusa MK i3 and create your First print.

Read More

item.title: Prusa 3D Model
item.dc:creator: cocopuncakes
item.description: Dive into the world of innovation with interactive 3D model of the Prusa i3 MK3! 🌐🛠️ Explore and learn about every intricate part of this cutting-edge printer right from your screen. From the extruder to the bed!🔍🔧
item.content:encoded:
Introduction to the Prusa MK i3 3D Model

The Prusa i3, an open-source 3D printer by Josef Prusa, is a widely embraced and influential device in the maker and 3D printing community. With a Cartesian frame, single extruder, and a heated print bed, it uses Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) to create objects layer by layer from melted thermoplastic filament. Being open source, the Prusa i3 encourages collaborative development, allowing users to modify and enhance the design. Over time, newer versions like the MK2, MK3, etc., bring improvements in features, reliability, and user-friendliness.

“Hang tight! Our model is working to provide you with the information you need, loading shortly.”

Click on numbers to see more information about different parts of PRUSA MK i3.

Prusa i3 MK3S by Innovation Wyrkshop on Sketchfab

item.title: Your First Print
item.dc:creator: cocopuncakes
item.description: Learn more about Prusa MK i3 and create your First print.
item.content:encoded:
Your First Print

This brief tutorial is designed to help you kickstart your printing journey with the PRUSA MK i3. Follow these simple steps to set up your printer and start creating amazing prints. Let’s get started!

If you want to lear more about different parts of Prusa MK i3. Click Learn more button.

Start tutorial
Learn more
LOADING FILAMENT

This steps just if filament is not loaded!

SPOOL OF FILAMENT

STEP 1

Secure the Filament Spool

  1. If you are using a spool of filament, ensure it is properly secured. Use the small holes on the sides of the spool holder to prevent any tangles or feeding issues during printing.
  2. Prepare the Filament:
    • Trim the molten end of the filament to form a sharp tip. Use side cutters for a clean cut. This step ensures a smooth and easy insertion into the printer.
 

Press the

LCD-knob

and choose the “Preheat” option from the menu, it will preheat to the temperature suitable for the material you plan to use( you can choose your filament type in LCD-menu. The preheating process helps soften the filament and prepares the printer for extrusion.

STEP 3

Insert Filament into the Extruder

  1. With the printer preheated, manually guide the sharp tip of the filament into the extruder body. Some printers have a specific entry point or a filament loading port. Ensure you follow the printer’s guidelines.

Check picture

STEP 4

Initiate Filament Insertion via LCD Menu

  1. Use the printer’s LCD menu to select the “Load Filament” option. Keep your fingers on the filament.
PRUSA
Slicer

– Accept G-code and more other formats
– Custom supports and modifier meshes
– Differential print settings
– Variable layer height
– Firmware flasher

Learn more
PRONTERFACE

– Use when USB connection needed
– Full control on 3D Printer
– Accept just G-code

Learn more
STEP 1
Slicing

When you download 3D models from the internet or create your own models, you will need to convert the 3D model (.stl, .obj.) into a set of instructions for the printer called G-code.

There are dozens of slicers available, each with their own advantages and disadvantages.

Check slicer tutorials

 

STEP 2
Inspection

 

1. Heatbed inspection
2. X-axis smooth rods inspection
3. Y-axis smooth rods inspection
4. Printer frame inspection

Wipe the dirt from the entire length of the smooth rods with a paper towel.
The surface must be clean, smooth, and without corrosion.

 

STEP 3
Innitialization

1. Power On:

Connect the printer to a power source and turn it on.

2. Preheat:

Preheat the printer to the recommended temperature for bed leveling. The printer must be preheated for the correct filament type. You can see the current stats in the main-info screen.

If you forget to preheat the printing nozzle and the bed before printing, the printer will automatically check the temperatures of the nozzle and the bed; printing will start when the desired temperature is reached – that can take several minutes

STEP 4
Printing

Choosing Print Modes on Prusa i3 MK3 3D Printer:

 

Stealth mode

Noise Level:

  • Printer is almost silent; fan noise is the primary sound.

    • Lost Step Detection:

  • Not available in Stealth mode.

    • Speed:

  • Printing is approximately 5-20% slower than in Normal mode, depending on the specific model.

    • Recommended For:

  • Users who prioritize an extremely quiet printing environment over lost step detection and are willing to trade a slight decrease in printing speed.

    • Normal

    Noise Level:

  • Quiet

    • Lost Step Detection:

  • Enabled in Normal mode.

    • Speed:

  • Generally faster compared to Stealth mode.

    • Recommended For:

  • Users prioritizing lost step detection and a balance between speed and noise.
    •  

    Press the

    LCD-knob

    and choose the Print from SD option from the menu, press to confirm and pick the desired model file_name.gcode.

    Watch the first few printed layers to be sure filament has attached to the bed properly (5 to 10 minutes).

     

    Recommendation:

    IPA at least 90%+(for everyday printing before every print) or WINDEX. Acetone once a week(reduce sticking of the bed)

    STEP 5
    Post-Processing

     

    1. Remove Print:

    Once the print is complete, remove bed in the beginning

    2. Clean and Store:

    Clean the bed with and store the printer properly for future use.

     

     

     
    TECHNIQUES FOR POST-PROCESSING

    After 3D printing a model, post-processing is often necessary to improve the final appearance, strength, and functionality of the printed object.

    Painting:

    • Painting is a common post-processing step for aesthetic purposes. Acrylic paints or other suitable paints can be applied to give the model its desired color and finish.

    Assembly:

    • If your model consists of multiple parts, post-processing may involve assembling them together. Techniques like gluing, snapping, or screwing parts together may be used.

    Support Removal:

    • If your 3D printer uses support structures to print overhangs or complex geometries, you may need to remove these supports carefully. This can be done using tools such as pliers, tweezers, or specialized support removal tools.

    Surface Smoothing:

    • Depending on the printing technology and material, the printed surface may have visible layer lines. Smoothing techniques such as sanding, filing, or using chemical smoothing agents can be applied to achieve a smoother finish.
